Award.AwardTitle: Engineering an Efficient Electron Pathway for Photosynthetic Hydrogen Production

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264289
Swartz, James R.

The long-term goal of this program is to engineer self-replicating bacterial systems to efficiently absorb sunlight and use the energy to split water and produce hydrogen. This crucial subproject is designed to provide fundamental insights required for the design of electron transfer pathways generally as well as the engineering and evolution of a specific photosynthetic hydrogen-producing pathway. The project will develop and apply methods that enable the evolution of a fusion protein that docks at photosystem I on a thylakoid membrane. The fusion protein will also be engineered and evolved to efficiently transfer electrons from the photosystem to an [FeFe] hydrogenase. The specific aims include (i)development of a high-throughput in vitro screen for hydrogen production driven by photosynthesis; (ii)engineering of a ferredoxin-hydrogenase fusion enzyme that produces hydrogen by coupling to photosystem I and (iii) the characterization of the productivity and oxygen sensitivity of the engineered photosynthetic hydrogen production system.
The broader impacts are significant both for training and technological applications. It will teach collaboration, teamwork and communication skills to a diverse group of students including minorities. The broader application of the principles revealed by this program could reshape the energy and chemical industries and help to provide a sustainable global socio-economic system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided a crucial capability needed for developing biological photosynthetic hydrogen technology. The final technology will allow us to use land unsuitable for raising crops to sustainably produce hydrogen as a fuel and an important raw material for making chemicals, especially nitrogen fertilizer. This technology would help maintain U.S. energy independence without significantly worsening global warming while also avoiding the need for the scarce and expensive metals used in alternative technologies. At the heart of this capability is the ability to extract electrons from water (using solar energy) and to transfer these electrons efficiently to the enzyme that requires them to produce the hydrogen, the hydrogenase.

Currently we have limited experience in designing such photosynthetic biological systems. The results from this project now allow us to mimic the biological electron transfer process in a test vial by activating the biological components with light and measuring the rate of hydrogen production. This new system is relatively easy to implement and has already provided important insights for designing efficient processes to produce hydrogen from sunlight and water.

The envisioned final technology would use a photosynthetic bacterium that will be genetically engineered to produce the hydrogen. In the native organism, a complex of proteins called photosystem II uses sunlight to split water, and a partnering complex called photosystem I (PSI) absorbs more light to boost the energy of the released electrons. PSI then sends these boosted electrons to other parts of the organism where CO­2 is captured and used to make biochemicals, proteins, and other cellular components. Another small protein called a Ferredoxin normally ferries the electrons from PSI to the intracellular components that make and maintain the cell.

In contrast, for hydrogen production we seek to divert most of those electrons coming from PSI to an enzyme that doesn’t normally occur in these cells, an [FeFe]-hydrogenase. This enzyme combines the electrons with protons (also derived from water splitting) to make the hydrogen. Of course, water also contains an oxygen atom and, during water splitting, molecular oxygen (O2) is released as a necessary by-product of photosynthesis. The oxygen causes problems since it can steal electrons from the photosystems and the electron carriers. This essentially forms a short circuit that lowers energy efficiency.  In addition, the oxygen can severely damage the [FeFe]-hydrogenase, killing its ability to make hydrogen. We sought to design our test tube reactions so that we could study all of these issues and design the components and the overall system to channel most of energy the cell absorbs from sunlight into chemical energy in the form of hydrogen.

Figure 1 illustrates the issues and the essence or our model system. Following the lead of previous investigators, we first purified PSI from the photosynthetic bacteria.  We then improved light-activated electron supply rates by optimizing the concentrations of Plastocyanin, a protein that helps deliver electrons to PSI. These components then supported robust light-dependent hydrogen production using the native Ferredoxin (Fd, SynFd in this case).  However, the hydrogenase (H2ase) has evolved to use a different Ferredoxin (CpFd).  We showed that CpFd can also receive electrons from PSI, but apparently provides no significant rate improvement for hydrogen production. We then added the electron transfer pathway that takes electrons toward cell biosynthesis (the normal pathway) by providing Ferredoxin NADP+ Reductase (FNR) and NADP+. With this more complex system, a mixture of the two ferredoxins provided faster hydrogen production. We next added Lactate DeHydrogenase (LDH) to harvest the electrons from NADPH thereby converting pyruvate to lactate. This more fully mimics normal metabolism. As expected, LDH helps pull electrons toward FNR.  However, when LDH is omitted and NADPH accumulates to mimic a cell deprived of CO2, electron flux goes primarily to produce hydrogen. We also used the system to show that the presence of O2 slows product formation when CpFd is used but not with SynFd indicating that the Fd from an anaerobic organism more readily loses electrons to oxygen (reaction in red). Finally Figure 2 illustrates how this system can also be used to show that the more oxygen tolerant [FeFe]-hydrogenases recently discovered in the Swartz lab can produce much more hydrogen in the presence of oxygen.

In summary, this grant provided the opportunity to develop an important analytical system as well as crucial insights into photosynthetic hydrogen production.  This moves us much closer to establishing feasibility for commercially viable photosynthetic hydrogen production.

Intellectual Merit:

  • New system mimics light dependent PSI electron supply with competitive consumption by: carbon fixation and biosynthesis, hydrogen production, and oxygen reduction.
  • Results indicate that CO2 limitation will allow robust hydrogen production.
  • System provides versatile platform for subsequent investigations including the development of improved system components.

Broader Impact:

For the first time, these results suggest feasibility for commercially viable photosynthetic hydrogen production, a technology that would help significantly in controlling global warming.
